entry.title: Cannon-Thurston maps: naturally occurring space-filling curves

media:group.media:title: Cannon-Thurston maps: naturally occurring space-filling curves
media:group.media:description:
Saul Schleimer and I attempt to explain what a Cannon-Thurston map is.
Thanks to my brother Will Segerman for making the carvings, and to Daniel Piker for making the figure-eight knot animations. I made the animation of the (super crinkly) surface using our app (with Dave Bachman) for cohomology fractals. You can play with the app (on Chrome or Firefox) at https://henryseg.github.io/cohomology_fractals/.
Also see: Cannon and Thurston, Group invariant Peano curves, Geom. Topol., 2007. Mumford, Series, and Wright, Indra's pearls, Cambridge University Press, 2002.
Some of these curves are available in t-shirt form at https://www.neatoshop.com/artist/Henry-Segerman.

entry.title: More circles on a sphere of cubes

media:group.media:title: More circles on a sphere of cubes
media:group.media:description:
This is a followup video to https://youtu.be/A2IAyXc0LuE.
The original Shadertoy demo: https://www.shadertoy.com/view/7ds3zB
The closest parallel planes: Suppose that v is an integer vector with no common factors between its coordinates. We want to find the integer vector u so that the component of u in the direction of v is as small as possible but still strictly positive. This component can be written using the dot product as u·v/|v|. Since v has no common factors between its coordinates, we can find an integer vector u so that u·v = 1. Thus the distance between the plane perpendicular to v and based at the origin and the parallel plane based at the end of u is 1/|v|. There is no closer plane, since u.v must be an integer.
Correction: the ripple frequency is proportional to the length of v, not inversely proportional. (Longer vectors have higher frequency ripples.)
